headline: With Portman endorsement, Ohio Senate candidate Jane Timken juggles opposing GOP factions
author: Haley BeMiller
sentences: That became ancient history to the former president after Timken briefly defended U.S. Rep. Anthony Gonzalez for voting to impeach him over the Jan. 6, 2021, insurrection, saying Gonzalez had a “rational reason why he voted that way."

She recently hired former Trump advisers Kellyanne Conway, David Bossie and Corey Lewandowski, although Lewandowski was ousted from Trump's super PAC after a prominent donor accused him of sexual harassment.

Haley BeMiller is a reporter for the USA TODAY Network Ohio Bureau, which serves the Columbus Dispatch, Cincinnati Enquirer, Akron Beacon Journal and 18 other affiliated news organizations across Ohio.

"I have a broad spectrum of supporters, and people know me as someone who's a true leader, who's been fighting for our conservative cause, and who's going to deliver for Ohio and America," Timken said.
“She’s doing all sorts of contortions to try to balance between the MAGA wing and the establishment wing of the Republican Party," said David Cohen, a political scientist at the University of Akron.
"You can’t run as the former party chair and not project a certain amount of insider political elitism," said David Niven, a political scientist at the University of Cincinnati.
Portman's endorsement is the most significant of the race so far, and Timken's campaign expected to immediately receive $800,000 from donors who waited for him to weigh in.
Ohio Republicans, like many across the country, are increasingly fed up with career politicians such as Portman and prefer the tactics of former President Donald Trump.

Angling for Trump's support
One person might have that kind of influence, and that's why Timken and her opponents have spent months trying to out-Trump each another.
Although she eventually called on Gonzalez to resign, observers say her comments sowed distrust among Ohio Trump supporters who will cast primary ballots this year.
Timken recently cut an ad casting her opponents as men who "overcompensate for their inadequacies," a stark contrast to the campaign style of mild-mannered Portman.
That leaves Timken in a bind as she and her GOP primary opponents work to ingratiate themselves with Trump – and she's working hard to wiggle her way out of it.
He easily won both of his Senate elections in 2010 and 2016 and established himself as a leading conservative voice who prefers policy work over bomb-throwing.
Portman announced last month that he's backing a longtime friend and former Ohio Republican Party chair in the crowded race to replace him in the U.S. Senate.
Portman spearheaded the bipartisan infrastructure deal that Timken opposed, largely because of a social spending package that Democrats sought to tie to it.
Timken, for her part, contends her candidacy as all-encompassing and doesn't see support from establishment and MAGA Republicans as an either/or prospect.
"She's got her own opinions, she's got her own conservative values, but she knows how to bring people together to actually achieve results," Portman said.
"I don’t think Portman has the ability to be the kingmaker in this race," said Kyle Kondik, an Ohio native and managing editor of Sabato's Crystal Ball.
In a GOP primary with several candidates and no clear front-runner, Portman's endorsement would typically be the most important get of the campaign.

Why Trump may be most important endorsement of all for Ohio Republicans
But this is no longer your father's Grand Old Party.
A recent poll from Emerson College found 38% of GOP voters said Portman's nod makes them less likely to support Timken.
Portman's endorsement and her time as party chair could complicate efforts to bring those voters back to her side.

Jane Timken and Rob Portman: Similarities and contrasts
Portman's endorsement of Timken was largely unsurprising.
Timken cast doubt on the 2020 election and said she wouldn't have voted to certify the results like Portman did.
His pitch for Timken was clear: She would unite different factions of the GOP to get the job done in Washington.
Timken was endorsed by key supporters of the former president, including U.S. Rep. Elise Stefanik of New York.
Most significantly, Timken boasts, Trump backed her bid for chair of the Ohio Republican Party in 2017.
The senator's wife, Jane Portman, already supported Timken, and the two families have a long history.
Portman also said Trump bore some responsibility for the Jan. 6 insurrection at the U.S. Capitol.
Timken also hired former Portman political strategist Corry Bliss at the onset of her campaign.
In Columbus last week, he touted Trump's policies on the economy and the U.S.-Mexico border.
His experience also comes with a large donor base to boost his preferred successor.
